title: 113_hr4831
content: The Act is titled the "Twenty-First Century Manufacturing Skills and Jobs Act of 2014". It includes provisions for federal matching payments for state new manufacturing jobs training tax credits. The Secretary of the Treasury will make quarterly payments to eligible community colleges based on new manufacturing job withholding matches. Eligible community colleges are public institutions offering 2-year associate's degrees that can be credited towards a baccalaureate degree. The State new manufacturing jobs training tax credit program is established for eligible community colleges and manufacturing employers to sign a contract for eligible trainees, where State income taxes withheld by the employer on behalf of the trainee can offset the training costs. The State income taxes withheld by the employer for eligible trainees will be remitted to the community college to offset training costs. The community college will treat these amounts as payment for education provided. The trainee's State income tax liability will be based on the remitted amounts. The contract between the community college and employer must meet program requirements. The contract between an eligible community college and a manufacturing employer must meet program requirements. It includes provisions for the college to provide qualified training to designated individuals without charging tuition, leading to full-time employment at the employer's job site. The eligible community college must provide tuition-free training to individuals hired by a manufacturing employer for full-time employment within the State. The employer must pay a wage of at least 175 percent of the Federal minimum wage or the State program amount. The employer will also remit State income taxes withheld on behalf of the individual to the community college for training costs. Qualified training under this section refers to education or training that equips individuals with the necessary skills for their job or to obtain required licenses. The training cost must be specified in the contract and deemed reasonable by market standards. Qualified training under this section includes education or skills necessary to obtain a license, certificate, or credential required by governmental regulations for the job. The program must be for new jobs and aligned with industry standards. The program for the credit must ensure that eligible trainees are hired for new jobs that result in a net increase in employment for the employer. The jobs must not be for recalled workers, replacements, or previously existing positions within the employer's business. The program ensures that eligible trainees are hired for new jobs resulting in a net increase in employment for the employer. Only U.S. employees are considered for the tax credit. All persons treated as a single employer under specific sections of the Internal Revenue Code are treated as a single employer for this purpose. Employers participating in the program may collaborate with local workforce investment boards. Employers or eligible community colleges in a State new manufacturing jobs training tax credit program can work with local workforce investment boards to hire and train eligible individuals. An eligible trainee is someone who received qualified training through a community college under the program, is employed full-time by the employer in the same state as the college, at a qualifying wage, and in a new job. The new manufacturing jobs training tax credit program allows eligible individuals who received qualified training from a community college to be employed full-time by an eligible manufacturing employer in the same state at a qualifying wage in a new job that requires the training. Eligible manufacturing employers must be engaged in manufacturing, have facilities in the United States, and be classified in sectors 31, 32, or 33 of the NAICS. Appropriations are made as needed to implement this program. The program allows eligible individuals trained by a community college to work for a manufacturing employer in sectors 31, 32, or 33 of NAICS. Appropriations are provided for program implementation. Remission of State Income Tax and tax treatment for eligible trainees are specified. The program allows eligible individuals trained by a community college to work for a manufacturing employer in sectors 31, 32, or 33 of NAICS. Remission of State Income Tax and tax treatment for eligible trainees are specified under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986.
